title.narrative: Debt Effectiveness of AIIB Loan for COVID-19 in the Philippines (DEAL)

description.narrative: The long -term objective of this project is to influence the direction of the ‘whole -of -government approach' by ensuring the effectiveness of AIIB loan facility to combat the spread of COVID -19 and mitigate its effects to local livelihoods. To achieve this long -term objective, the following specific objectives are set out: 2. Specific Objectives: • Enhance spaces for meaningful CSO participation in mechanisms within government's implementing agencies to do proper targeting, tracking of results • Actively promote the consideration of the differentiated needs of women and girls in the development of plans for and measuring the results of the proceeds from loan; and, • Citizens assessment of the implementation informs the refinement of plans of the government and the policies of AIIB.

title.narrative: Cash for Work Opportunities,Covid-19 Awareness & Prevention of Women in Mindanao

description.narrative: Reduced gender -based risks and negative impacts of COVID 19 among women and other vulnerable groups in partner community: Output 1: 550 Women enrolled in cash -for -work (CFW) under the project and other livelihood support schemes or programs 1.1 Number of women enrolled in and provided with prepaid cards for receiving digital and real time cash transfers 1.2 Number of women who received and used cash -for -work support based on their identified local livelihood projects 1.3 Percentage of women and other vulnerable groups reached by the project who reported improved financial and/or livelihood knowledge and skills Output 2: Information -sharing and influencing for improved COVID 19 awareness and positive gender norms initiated by women's groups/advocates 2.1. mailing-address.narrative: Oxfam House, John Smith Drive, Oxford, OX4 2JY

title.narrative: Creating Space to Take Action on Violence Against Women and Girls- ( COVID-19 )

description.narrative: The proposed five year program will reduce violence against women and girls, and the prevalence of early, forced and child marriage. The program will achieve this ultimate outcome through a holistic, multi -pronged and multi -generation approach to ending violence against women and girls. First, it will create an enabling environment to prevent violence against women and girls by engaging key, influential religious, community, private sector and political leaders as well as young men and women in advancing women's leadership, women's rights and the elimination of violence against women and girls. These community leaders and youth will act as champions of change, decreasing the social acceptability of violence and modeling positive behaviors within the social spheres in which they are most influential. Training will be undertaken for them to better understand the rights of women and girls, the different forms of violence, as well as the role they each must play in ending violence. Practical tools will be developed to ensure these actors are supported in their on -going efforts to model positive behaviors. The program will include annual round tables and exchange visits to strategise long -term solutions and build momentum around prevention. In addition, the program will support key religious, community, private sector and political leaders to strengthen or change standards, legislation, and regulations. A comprehensive, context -specific baseline analysis will be undertaken in each program location.

mailing-address.narrative: Oxfam House, John Smith Drive, Oxford, OX4 2JY

sector.narrative: Right to Equity: Gender and Diversity

title.narrative: Empower Youth for Work in Pakistan ( COVID-19 )

description.narrative: The project's ambition is that young people in Pakistan are empowered and have improved skills and jobs. This is a multi -country project that includes Bangladesh, Ethiopia and Indonesia in addition to Pakistan. This program focuses specifically on Small Medium Enterprise (SME) development; improved jobs; skills development for youth; climate change, and Life Skills. This project works with holistic approach working around three building blocks 1. Agency, capacity and skills 2. Economic opportunities 3. Policy and norms Youth will be co -creators and co -implementers. Through civil society partners, and close links with the private sector and government institute, we ensure that improved skills training is adopted within local structures and innovative social enterprises; unemployment is tackled through improved private sector practice, increased market access and new enterprise development; an enabling social environment is created through grassroots and mass media action. Climate change, resilience, gender and youth empowerment are mainstreamed. 70% of beneficiaries will be rural young women. Overall it aspires to economically empower the rural youth especially young girls by imparting the required soft and market led skills to engage in economic learning cycle. But in order to fulfil this aspiration we need to build the confidence of girls by imparting Life Skills Based Education which in turn will pave the path for economic empowerment. Additionally none of this is possible until and unless policy and practice level change is in place in both districts Jamshoro (Sindh) and Layyah (Punjab). So mobilisation and lobbying with government and private sector companies (inclusive of Micro Enterprises (MEs), Small Medium Enterprise (SME) and Multi -National Corporations (MNCs) to make pro youth and specifically pro girls working environment shall also be carried out.

sector.narrative: Right to Equity: Gender and Diversity

title.narrative: Resilience Development Program in Badin, Pakistan ( Covid-19 )

description.narrative: The five -year project aims to improve the resilience of rural communities and government authorities in Badin to build understanding, knowledge and skills to prepare for, adapt to and mitigate climate and disaster risks. This includes adopting climate -smart agricultural techniques, diversifying livelihoods, and applying an appropriately designed risk transfer mechanism which will be developed in partnership with non -traditional actors including micro -insurance. The project specifically targets women, young people, and people with disabilities who are particularly vulnerable to the impacts of disasters and climate change in Badin.

title.narrative: Emergency Response in Balochistan/ COVID-19 Response

description.narrative: Drought affected 1,924 families in selected districts of Balochistan have improved health and hygiene and water storage facility. Drought affected 1,924 households/families have improved income through provision of livestock fodder. The program directly contributes to Oxfam's mandate of providing humanitarian assistance during emergencies and prepare people for future disasters. The proposed project directly targets most vulnerable drought affected men and women living in remote and poor areas of the country. The program is expected to improve Health and Hygiene and Livelihood conditions of the targeted 1,924 families which are suffering from severe food shortage and loss of livelihood.

mailing-address.narrative: Oxfam House, John Smith Drive, Oxford, OX4 2JY

title.narrative: Humanitarian Response to the COVID-19 pandemic

description.narrative: The expanding global outbreak of the Coronavirus remains uncontrolled with total confirmed cases 533,015 (Globally) and total deaths 24,095 as of 27 -3 -2020 in 199 Countries and Territories. The confirmed case fatality ratio is still being assessed. As of 27th April, there have been more than 12,723 confirmed cases of COVID -19 in Pakistan, with 281 deaths reported. The estimated total population of Pakistan is around 220.89 million making it the fifth most populous country in the world with approximately two -thirds of the population residing in rural areas with no access to hospitals equipped to deal with coronavirus patients, or sometimes to any medical facilities at all. Owing to poor health seeking behaviours a weak health system in Pakistan, it is feared that the identified cases may be just the tip of the iceberg. Considering the impact of COVID -19 pandemic disaster impact, it is proposed that key measures be undertaken rapidly to prevent and contain the further spread of the infection in Pakistan. As duty of care for staff, partners, and vulnerable communities, large gatherings will be avoided through above mentioned outsourced channels where possible. A key consideration would be to adopt strategies which prevent panic and paranoia amongst the people and ensure safety of the targeted population. The approaches for this is outlined below: - Mass awareness and communications campaign for Infection prevention and control - Provision of WASH Service and Supplies and personal protective equipment - Addressing the economic crisis through relief support - Promoting livelihood diversification and entrepreneurship - Supporting protection and shelter mechanisms for women, girls and marginalized groups

Cash assistance to 123 workers (106 women and 17 men) employed by the women cooperatives and have witnessed the cuts in employment due to the crisis. 2. title.narrative: Response to the Victims of Floods and support to COVID-19 awareness in Rwanda

description.narrative: This 45 days project implementation period will be appropriate for the immediate needs while the medium to long term needs arising from the floods damage are being planned for and additional resources mobilised under the coordination of the government. This response will also provide a complimentary response to the food assistance currently under way to meet the immediate gaps. Moreover, as Rwanda continues the fight of COVID -19, the project will be instrumental to mitigate the spread of COVID -19 for the affected population as it will allow targeted households to go to their homes, and leave temporary shelter where conditions are not conducive to required hygiene and social distancing for COVID -19 prevention. Based on the identified needs and the proposed funding amount, this project prioritizes the basic lifesaving responses: 1. Shelter: Distribution of basic construction materials such as iron sheets and galvanized wires. 2. Non -food Items (NFIs): Distribution of critical and strategic NFIs such as Blankets, Mats, Jerricans, Bathing soap, Washing soap, Buckets, Pads, Tooth brushes, Tooth Pastes, Saucepans, Plates, Cups and Folks. 3.WASH: The will intervention will ensure that the floods victims have access to the basic m basic hygiene and sanitation items. The project will also contibute to the beneficiaries' hygiene behaviour change towards disaster and COVID -19, contributing to the ongoing efforts on DRR and COVID -19 awareness.This includes early floods warnign messaging and COVID -19 wareness among the affected population and targeted Districts. This project component will work with pre -existing disaster risk reduction structures in the communities to intensify DRR and COVID -19 awareness.

title.narrative: COVID-19 response in South Sudan

description.narrative: The response programme has the overall objective of providing immediate support to decrease public health risks from COVID -19 to 500,000 men women and children who are particularly vulnerable to COVID -19 pandemic through a WASH and markets -based assistance. The project mainly focuses on raising awareness of the community on COVID -19 prevention and strengthening the capacity of local health facilities to help them provide prevention and care services. The project will be implemented through local partners in some locations like Pibor, Rumbek and Juba while Oxfam directly implement the project in Akobo and Wau.

title.narrative: 2019 Response to Flood Affected Victims and COVID-19 in Sierra Leone

description.narrative: Through this emergency intervention, Oxfam, Action Against and Hunger and local actors will focus on providing Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) and livelihood packages to 1,107 households (Mothers of Under 5s, damaged households and female headed households) in targeted communities. Key activities to support the intervention are, distribution of drinking water (Water trucking), establishment of emergency water kiosks in targeted areas, disinfection of water points and rehabilitation of water facilities, rehabilitation of public toilets, provision of Non Food Item (NFI) Kits including women dignity kits and mosquito nets, provision of PUR sachets, hygiene promotions and radio campaigns, training on emergency water treatment for Ministry Department and Agencies and WASH committee members, Multi -purpose cash transfer , De -Silting, cleaning of drains (Community Campaign) and Cash for Work. These activities will support the project objectives which seeks to Provide safe drinking water and repair and maintenance of WASH facilities, Conduct Public Health Promotion activities as well as provision of sanitation materials for affected population and Restoration of Livelihood through provision of conditional and unconditional cash grant

title.narrative: Strengthening preparedness & response to cholera, COVID-19 in Harare by Jan 2021

description.narrative: The project seek to improve access to clean and safe water as well as as improve hygiene practise to combat Covid 19, cholera and typhoid incidence. Oxfam and Harare Water will conduct technical assessments which will inform rehabilitation of 38 water points and 4 solar piped water schemes in Harare Metro, in densely populated suburbs . Water quality assessment shall be conducted on the target water points to determine the fitness of the water for human consumption, prior to rehabilitation. To ensure sustainability of the water points, Oxfam shall train water point committees on the Community Based Management (CBM) concept for the management of the water points. The project shall also upgrade 4 solar powered water schemes with a water kiosk to promote the operations and maintenance of the system. WASH Rapid Response Team (RRT) intervention through hygiene awareness and contact tracing to suspected cases. The intervention shall also distribute NFI to vulnerable households. Public toilets shall also be rehabilitated for communities in high densely populated suburbs.

title.narrative: Partnership for Building Urban Resilience in Glen View and Budiriro for 8 months

description.narrative: Oxfam will respond to COVID -19 in partnership with City of Harare in improving access to clean water and service delivery at market stores and other public places. Soap and water will be distributed at market stores as well as handwashing stations. Oxfam will work with community health volunteers in hygiene promotion and risk communication to strengthen local capacity in the target communities on WASH. Oxfam will support establishment of a gender and risk analysis on COVID -19 to assess the impacts on different groups of people at water points to develop and implement mitigation measures for prevention of sexual exploitation and abuse. Oxfam will support coordination and decision making for gender inclusive at local and national level and mainstreaming GBV during radio talk shows and loud hailers during hygiene promotion.

title.narrative: Residual Cyclone Idai & Emergency Response to COVID 19 in Chipinge for 9 months

description.narrative: The project seek to reduce the impact of COVID 19 through improving access to safe water, hygiene promotion and improving access to sanitation. Improved access to clean water shall be achieved through rehabilitation of 73 water points, training of 73 Water points user committees, Water quality monitoring of 73 water points, training of 73 Village Pump Mechanics, training of 20 EHTs. Knowledge and hygiene practise shall be improved through refresher training of 25 Community Health Volunteers, establishment / revival of 25 Community Health Clubs, distribution of 12170 hygiene kits, door to door campaigns ,rehabilitation of 20 water and sanitation facilities in 11 Health Care centres. Improved access to sanitation shall be achieved through the construction of 6 squat hole latrines at 2 health care centres

title.narrative: Understanding immediate impacts of Covid-19 on coastal communities in Mozambique

description.narrative: The project aims to fill critical gaps in our understanding of the socioeconomic and environmental impacts of Covid-19 on coastal communities in northern Mozambique. The data will inform development of coping mechanisms for communities, increase resilience to shocks and support recommendations for scalable community-based solutions. We will focus on enhancing knowledge around key pillars including governance and co-management of marine resources, community behaviour and biological impact on fisheries, to inform the knowledge base and strategies for long term community resilience.

title.narrative: EU Scholarship Programme for the Turkish Cypriot community 2019-21

description.narrative: The EU Scholarship Programme for the Turkish Cypriot Community is being delivered by the British Council in Cyprus under a 43 month Delegation Agreement with the European Commission to implement the action for the calls for two academic years 2019/20 and 2020/21. The contract duration was extended to 55 months to manage the underspent which resulted from the withdrawal of scholars who could not start their studies because of Covid-19 pandemic. The value of the contract, however, remained the same. The EU Scholarship Programme is fully funded by the European Commission and forms part of one of four aid strands operated by the EU for the Turkish Cypriot Community.

The Programme included the following activities: 1) Launch & promotion of the calls 2) Application & recruitment process 3) Selection process including the delivery of written tests 4) Awards for successful applicants 5) Contract signing with beneficiaries 6) Monitoring & Evaluation 7) Alumni & Visibility activities 8) Final payment and closure of the Call

The Programme's target groups are final year high school students, graduates of high schools, final year undergraduate students, postgraduate students, University graduates and professionals from various sectors of the community.

The objective of the Programme is to offer the Turkish Cypriot Community additional educational opportunities by raising their knowledge and/or increasing their skills in a specific field as well as broadening their experience of studying and working in the European Union, thus bringing them closer to the European Union.

mailing-address.narrative: 1 Redman Place, London E20 1JQ, UK

name.narrative: Nicosia (covering the Northern part of Cyprus territory)

title.narrative: Agents for Citizen-Driven Transformation (ACT): Implementation Phases

description.narrative: Gender and Social Inclusion (G&SI) is a cross-cutting focus of the programme. ACT will provide both technical and financial support to its partners to become fully aware and mainstream G&SI in their internal process and programme activity implementation. ACT is supporting national/local CSOs that are working in the area of advocacy for PWD and women issues. ACT is contibuting to humanitarian activities through its focused support to its CSO partners to become socially responsible and committed to increasing awareness and compliance to safety procols for COVID-19 at the community level in selected states - Lagos, Kano, Sokoto and FCT.

The Agents for Citizen-driven Transformation (ACT) programme aims to contribute to the achievement of sustainable development in Nigeria through enhancing the credibility of Civil Society Organisations (CSO) and enhancing their role as independent development actors and drivers of change.

The overall Objective of the programme is to contribute to more inclusive, effective, accountable and gender-responsive development in Nigeria. The Specific Objective of the programme is to enhance the credibility and role of CSOs as drivers of change for sustainable development in Nigeria.
Result One: Strengthened selected CSOs, Networks and Coalitions working in the three EU focal sectors.
Result Two: Appropriate and inclusive civil society regulatory framework in place.

The target beneficiaries of the programme are selected CSOs at the state and national levels. Additionally, other stakeholders such as the regulatory agencies and selected CSO Capacity Development Providers (CDPs) will also receive capacity strengthening support from the programme. The programme will also benefit community members indirectly through provision of small scale capacity development grants for CSO partners that will implement actvities at the community level with strategic connections to the issues of concern to vulnerable groups including PWDs, women, young people amongst others. The programme beneficiaries will spread across ten selected states of Nigeria: Lagos, Kano, Sokoto, Federal Capital Territory (FCT), Adamawa, Rivers, Edo, Enugu, Borno and Plateau/Kwara.

title.narrative: Yemen Complex Emergency 2014

description.narrative: After more than four years, the conflict in Yemen that has brought about a man-made humanitarian disaster affecting 22.5 million people. Â As a result of the protracted violence, thousands of civilians have been killed or injured, and millions displaced. Widespread damage to public infrastructure and severe shortage of supplies, owing to restrictions on the movement of goods into and within the country, make it nearly impossible for the majority of Yemenis to obtain food, water, medical care and other essentials. Â Wounded and sick people are unable to obtain timely and good-quality health services, because of the dangers associated with seeking such services. Most hospitals are seriously handicapped by the lack of medicines, equipment and trained staff. National capacities for tackling public-health emergencies, such as cholera outbreaks, are very limited. Â Millions of people have been displaced since the conflicts began; many are still unable to return home. A large part of the population is heavily dependent on humanitarian aid and faces food insecurity. They struggle to obtain or produce food, and to resume or sustain their livelihoods, because of the fighting and movement restrictions. The unavailability of potable water and of adequate sanitation facilities puts many of them at risk of disease or illness. Â Attacks against humanitarian personnel are not uncommon. Since the escalation of the conflict in March 2015, seven Yemen Red Crescent Society volunteers and three ICRC personnel have been killed while carrying out their duties. The few international organizations present in the country struggle to respond to the outstanding needs of victims. Â

BRC is contributing GBP 125,000 in un-earmarked funds to the ICRC Covid-19 response in Yemen. The funds will support ICRC Yemen activities with a focus on supporting health infraestructure, preventing the spread of disease in places of detention, ensuring community access to clean water and reinforcing good hygiene practices and promoting resilience in quarantine centres.

BRC is contributing GBP 125,000 in un-earmarked funds to the ICRC Covid-19 response in Yemen. The funds will support ICRC Yemen activities with a focus on supporting health infraestructure, preventing the spread of disease in places of detention, ensuring community access to clean water and reinforcing good hygiene practices and promoting resilience in quarantine centres.

title.narrative: Sahel Cash Preparedness programme

description.narrative: Â The CASH preparedness programme is intensive mentoring scheme by a dedicated Programme Lead to institutionalise and embed cash based support into NS of the SAHEL's existing disaster preparedness and food security/livelihoods systems. The first phase of the programme which ended in summer of 2020 focussed on the Mali RC, Burkina RC and Niger RC.Â The Lead will be a technical specialist who coordinates and develops the bespoke training and coaching, ensures coordination and participation with technical leaders in the field and feeds into the body of learning and tools being developed by the Movement Cash Peer Working Group which is being coordinated by the IFRC cash unit in Geneva. The Programme Lead also ensures there are opportunities for peer to peer exchanges between the participating regional National Societies. The second phase of this programme which will run over the next two years will focus on Chad and Mauritania RC Societies.Â
Second payment for 2020.Â Progress reports show little spending, but this is explained by COVID lockdown. A GAD addendum has been signed to extend the timeframe.Â

title.narrative: Caribbean Hurricane Resilience Programme

description.narrative: The Caribbean Response Preparedness and Resilience Programme (Anguilla, BVI and TCI) is the second phase of the Hurricane Irma and Maria Response Programme in these territories. Â The programme aims to strengthen the capacity of local Red Cross Branches in the British Overseas Territories (OTs) of Turks & Caicos Islands (TCI), British Virgin Islands (BVI) and Anguilla to better support people in crises during disasters. Â

title.narrative: Zimbabwe Cash Preparedness

description.narrative: Start and End dates: 23rd April 2019 â€“ 31st August 2021 Summary:Â Resilience through Disaster Response Management; Multipurpose Cash Preparedness and Comprehensive School SafetyWorking with the Finnish Red Cross, and WFP - Based in Harare and Mangwe district 1.Â Â Â Â Â Â Strengthened capacities to use multi-purpose cash transfer as a mean of humanitarian aid delivery mechanism 2.Â Â Â Â Â Â Children and youth, and their home communities, are more resilient to disasters and have safer learning environments through the enhanced contribution of the Red Cross to the Comprehensive School Safety Framework in Zimbabwe. 3.Â Â Â Â Â Â Distribution of first aid, basic safety and student care equipment to schools as well as distribution of IEC materials for youth and children. title.narrative: SGBV Prevention and Response in Disasters - Asia

description.narrative: This project aims to prevent and reduce the occurrence of sexual and gender based violence at the community level, particularly in times of crisis. As gender based violence is closely linked to harmful gender based norms and beliefs, it will also seek to change attitudes toward violence in order to decrease the tolerance of sexual and gender based violence. Â In the Philippines the project will be piloted in between four to six communities, in Tacloban city and Aklan province. The chosen communities will be confirmed, based on planning mission reports, and agreed to once at the inception workshop at the start of the project. Â In Indonesia, the project will be piloted in between three to six communities in Aceh province and Bima City. If successful and dependant on the level of funding available the project could then be scaled-up, rolled out to other communities, and potentially implemented in other countries in the region. Â This project will primarily work with women and girls as they are disproportionally affected by SGBV. However, we know from experience that exclusion of men and boys in such programmes distorts household dynamics and results in more violence towards women and girls and as such men and boys will also be engaged as key participants in this project. Â

Due to a lack of progress within PMI, and the effect of COVID-19 on the project overall, it has been agreed with the donor, IFRC, PMI and PRC, to extend the timeframe of this project by one year. This is a no cost extension from the donor and will allow completion of all project activities as originally intended. Therefore, rather than end on the 31st December 2020, this project will now end on the 31st December 2021. Â Since the project has been extended for one year to 31st December 2021, the BRC has agreed to fund the programme management position which maintains oversight of this project for the extension period. The PGI officer is the main link between BRC and PMI and PRC on this, and so the position it critical to the continuation of the project. The BRC, IFRC and donor agree to utilise a small underspend on the project (14, 732 CHF) towards this position, and BRC will contribute a further 53,148 CHF equivalent of GBP 44,852 in order to fully fund the position from the end of the previous period 31st December 2020 until the 31st December 2021. This position extension will therefore be from the 1st January 2021- 31st December 2021. Â Regarding reporting, interim reports shall be submitted in December 2020, April,2021 and October,2021. The final narrative and financial reports shall be submitted on 31st March,2022, (with the narrative outcomes and impacts only for SGBV project). The financial report would reflect total amount of expenses against full amount of pledged funds for all respective projects under cash pledge M1812018.

Final tranch for SGBV.Â All docs present - PMN and GAD Addendum are for multiple positions / programmes, of which this grant is one. Documents atÂ https://pims-live.redcross.org.uk/entity/6/P7848-001/documents?folderPath=Final%20Tranch

title.narrative: GRC-YRCS Primary Health Centres (Hajjah,Al Dhalee)

description.narrative: Since the escalation of violence in March 2015, the healthcare sector in Yemen has been unable to respond to the rising needs. This intervention is a continuation of BRC's support to German Red Cross's in YRCS's health facilities in Yemen. It covers YRCS Health Centre and Emergency Obstetrics clinic in Hajjah, which has been supported by BRC since April 2016; and the extended support to the Al Dhalee Health Centre, which GRC has been supporting since 2019. The project's overall objective is that conflict-affected people have access to emergency medical care and primary health care free of charge at YRCS health facilities. This will be achieved through the provision of drugs/medical supplies and supporting with operating and staff costs. Â Since April 2016, the British Red Cross (BRC) has been successful in funding the EmOC unit; securing Â£30,000 from the Jersey Overseas Aid Committee (JOAC) in 2016 and Â£140,000 from the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) (Feb- Dec 2018). Both contributions have supplemented BRCâ€™s own appeal funds. Â In 2019 BRC has committed to continuing its support to EmOC with Â£480,000 for a further 24 months until Feb 2021.This is a mixture of restricted funds secured from the Isle of Man government (Â£81,989), and Volant (Â£100,000), supplemented bv BRCâ€™s own Emergency Appeal funds. In 2021, BRC entered a new agreement with GRC to support an additional health centre in Al Dhalee.

title.narrative: Namibia Food Insecurity 2019/2020

description.narrative: Start and End dates: 20th June 2019 - TBC Summary:Â On May 6, 2019, Dr Hage Geingob, President of the Republic of Namibia declared a state of emergency due to poor rainfall and the prevalent drought within the country. To complement this, the Namibia Red Cross Society, Spanish Red Cross and British Red Cross collaborated to support 599 HHs over a period of four months. Cash assistance has not been used as a standard response modality in Namibia but for this project the Government of Namibia has agreed that the NRCS could trial the distribution of cash among affected HHs and farmers.In October 2019, the government of Namibia extended the state of emergency and national disaster period by six months to March 2020Â stating that the number of people in need of aid had more than tripled to 900,000 (more than 30% of the population) Location: Sibbinda Constituency, Zambezi Region, Namibia Bens: Phase 1 = 599HHÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Phase 2 = additional 612HH = 1,211 HH Donor: None â€“ However Â£75K for Phase 1 and Â£200K for Phase 2 came from DF PNSs: Spanish Red Cross and German RC Budget: Phase 1 BRC sent Â£175K and Phase 2 BRC sent an additional 200KÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Q4 2019:Â In September 2019, additional funding provided by the German Red Cross and German Government expanded the intervention within the targeted communities registering an additional 612 households raising the total to 1,211 households. The intervention was later extended to March 2020 with additional cash distributions added in November, January, February and March. April 2020: Â Funds for a PMEAL training that had to be cancelled due to COVID19 and some extra funds from a favourable exchange rate are going to be used for COVID 19 response. Spanish report cross have agreed for us to extend this emergency till April 2020 with a final report in May 2020.Â

title.narrative: COVID-19 Outbreak

description.narrative: On 31 December 2019, WHO was alerted to several cases of pneumonia in Wuhan City, Hubei Province of China. This virus was later identified as a new virus and has been named â€œ2019-nCoV.â€ The new virus is a coronavirus, which is a family of viruses that include the common cold, and viruses such as SARS and MERS. On the 30th January 2020, Coronavirus was declared a public health emergency of international concern by WHO. On the 28th February 2020 the WHO upgraded the global risk from the coronavirus to "very high." On the 11th Feb the virus was officially named COVID-19: - The name is taken from the words "corona", "virus" and "disease", 2019 representing the year that it emerged. - The word coronavirus refers to the group of viruses it belongs to, rather than the latest strain. - The virus itself has been designated SARS-CoV-2 by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses. On the 11th March the coronavirus outbreak was labelled a pandemic by WHO.

title.narrative: Iraq Programming

description.narrative: The French Red Cross (FRC) has been operational in Northern Iraq alongside the Iraqi Red Crescent (IRCS) since 2013, especially in Dohuk, Ninewah and Erbil governorates so far. Focused first on the influx of Syrian refugees, then on the IDP crisis and the challenging displacements and returns of population, FRC provides assistance in a range of sectors including WASH, livelihoods, education, shelter and relief in cooperation with the IRCS Current programming includes WASH, Livelihoods, Education and Psychosocial Support and Disasters Preparedness and Disasters Reduction thematic. Mainstreaming of the capacity building of the Iraqi Red Crescent (IRCS) in FRCâ€™s daily work is also a main priority. Sinjar District in Northern Iraq is still facing a number of challenges following the liberation in 2015 from ISIS, with a large amount of the population still being displaced within Iraq. The current outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic and the accompanying lockdowns and curfews have put additional economic pressure on the population. In recent months, an increase in returns of IDPs to Sinjar could be observed, 14,704 individuals (2,711 families) have arrived between 8 June and 12 August 2020 (IOM data). With much of the houses, farms, and key infrastructure destroyed or still contaminated with unexploded ordinance, people returning are facing difficulties re-establishing their livelihoods.Present in Sinjar since 2016, FRC has visited several of the affected communities currently receiving returnees in August 2020, and in addition has collected information from secondary sources such as UNHCR, district representatives, and local NGOs. All sources confirm water supply as one of the key needs.Â Â BRC completed an evaluation of one of the programmes; Cash-For-Work (CFW) through WASH project in Iraq in 2019 and found the cash-based component of the project was successful. The evaluation report recommended implementing remaining Iraq appeal funds in Sinjar to build on the previous WaSH and CFW implemented in that area and to support people, including SGBV survivors, impacted by displacement and protracted conflict.Â Therefore, the Iraq WaSH and MPCA project in Sinjar has two key areas of work: firstly the rehabilitation of two boreholes for recently returned IDPs to stop the dependence on water trucking. Secondly a one-off MPCA for 115 HHs and 50 GBV survivor households.Â Â Â Â Â

title.narrative: Eswatini Silele Community Project

description.narrative: Summary: Working through the Baphalali Eswatini Red Cross' Clinic in Silele we are reaching the community through three elements â€“ 1)Â Â Â Â Â Water and Sanitation Rehabilitation of the Water system for the Silele Clinic, Water Committees, Rain water Harvesting and water tank construction, Train BERCS staff in WASH, Hand washing facilities at schools and awareness, Demonstration HHs 2)Â Â Â Â Â Menstrual Hygiene Management Learning workshop with Malawi, Lesotho and Uganda RC, Parental support groups, Teen clubs training, making sanitary pads (potentially), Construct MHM friendly latrine at Silele Clinic, Awareness raising for PSEA 3)Â Â Â Â Â Nutrition Awareness raising on healthy eating and indigenous foods, Key hole gardens demonstration at Silele Clinic, Cooking demonstrations, Community Nutritional status database, Food supplements for mothers and children, Anthropometric kits for the Clinic Location: Silele Clinic and Community in the Shiselweni region Bens: Unknown at the moment Â Donor: Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Di Moody Legacy Fund - Â£350,000 Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â PPL - Â£12,250 Â·Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Finnish Red Cross - â‚¬55,000 PNSs: Finnish Red Cross Budget:Â Â£409,250 for the entire programme Situation - Dec 2019: Assessment phase is ongoing from Oct '19 - March '20. A Wash officer has been hired who will start in Jan 2020. The MHM workshop took place in Nov '19; govt are still unsure around reusable sanitary pads. In depth assessment plans are being established for the next 2/3 months before the final programme design is completed and confirmed Situation â€“ June 2020: Assessment and Planning stage has been delayed due to COVID but close to completion, the Logframe has been finalised, implementation is hopefully going to start asap. title.narrative: Ethiopia, Sudan and Djibouti population movement 2020/2021

description.narrative: Wednesday 4th November 2020, Ethiopian Prime Minister confirmed a state of emergency and launched a military operation for 6 months in the Tigray region agaisnt The Tigray People's Liberation Front (TPLF) - a historically powerful political party.Â IFRC have approved DREFs for specific responses in Ethiopia and Sudan and there is potential for an Emergency AppealÂ During the recent years, parts of Ethiopia, Sudan and Djibouti have been affected by the compounded effects of climatic shocks (leading to droughts and floods, the locust infestation and disease outbreaks) and the spread of COVID-19, impacting peopleÂ´s coping capacities. The eruption of armed violence in Tigray in early November has triggered a humanitarian crisis while exacerbating other underlying vulnerabilities.Â Â Â As leading humanitarian actors and front-line responders, often where others do not have access, the components of the Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement are present in all three countries and coordinate closely to respond to critical needs of people affected by multiple vulnerabilities, particularly in the fields of protection, health, psychosocial support (PSS), restoring family links (RFL), economic security and water and sanitation, The IFRC and the ICRC have launched coordinated appeals, seeking a total of CHF 47 million to scale up humanitarian activities and strengthen coordination systems in a multi-country approach

BRC contribution to SRCS Protection and PFA trained-volunteers, to support the Ethiopia Population Movement emergency operations and the influx of refugees into Eastern Sudan. Payment via Danish RC and to bridge the gap before the Â£1mill PPL programme starts in 2021Â
BRC payment of Â£150,000 to IFRC Emergency Appeal for Ethiopia, Sudan and Djibouti complex crisisÂ
Payment to IFRC to cover 3 months of the Ethiopia Ops Manager for the Population Movement EmergencyÂ

title.narrative: Kenya Locusts, Floods & COVID 2020

description.narrative: Situation: in addition to the COVID outbreak, there is ongoing flooding and locust swarms. Flooding is widespread, affecting 43 counties. KRCS is doing a Locust Impact assessment funded by FAO and there is an inter-agency floods assessment being done. IFRC response: There is an open floods EA, Locust EA covering Kenya, Ethiopia, Somalia, Uganda and South Sudan (launched 17/04/2020, for 1.8mill CHF, 9 months) and of course COVID country plan and regional COVID EPoA.Â BRC support: Â£300k DF pledge to support KRCS bi-laterally in the response to these emergencies. Many of the same communities are being affected simultaneously by all three. In-line with conversations happening at different forums, there is a need for us to support partners integrated responses as much as possible. It does not make sense operationally and in terms of value for money to separately support 3 different IFRC EAs and with KRCS a long term partner, bi-lateral support is the best option. How KRCS will use the funds: Plan with KRCS DM team. The proposal is to support communities with multi-purpose cash, to 2145 HH over 3 months (July-Sept 2020), with risk communication (consolidated messaging of the various risks.) The cash intervention will be an expansion of an existing programme, so everything is already in place.
This transfer request covers the first 2 months of activities of the response. Support documents are saved here

title.narrative: Beirut explosion 2020

description.narrative: The explosion at the Port of Beirut at 6:10pm on Tuesday 4th August 2020 caused extensive damage, loss of life and has impacted hundreds of thousands of people in Beirut. As of 25th September, over 190 people are reported to have died, with more than 6,500 people injured. The Government of Lebanon estimates that around 300,000 people were made homeless following the Beirut Port explosion and up to 40,000 buildings sustained damage. The explosion occurred while Lebanon faces a deep economic and political crisis, and rising COVID-19 cases. Protests against the Lebanese government have been taking place for months in Beirut prompting the Government to step down on 10 August 2020. Poverty has risen in recent months; 2.7 million residents are now poor and 1.1. million are extremely poor. The Lebanese Red Cross immediately mobilized its teams and assets to respond to the blast. They have launched a one-year Response Plan appealing for $125 million to respond to the needs of those affected by the multiple overlapping shocks faced by many in Lebanon during 2020.

Please see attached the GAD and supporting documentation for the DF allocation to the DMU of LRC in response to the Beirut explosion.Â On 4 August a large explosion occurred in the port of Beirut, killing over 170 people and injuring an estimated 6,000. A number of sectors of Greater Beirut have been significantly affected by the blast - businesses and infrastructure have been destroyed or damaged, and up to 300,000 people are thought to have lost their homes. The Disaster Management Sector at the Lebanese Red Cross will be providing a several tier response with both direct response to the blast in coordination with Blood Transfusion services and long-term objectives to improve the living conditions of the affected population through the provision ofÂ shelters and basic needs to 10,000 families in a three months response through 3 phases: Phase one: Conduct a Post Disaster Assessment (PDA) followed by a door-to-door emergency needs assessment and Damage Assessment and Needs Analysis (DANA) accompanied with distribution of ready-made meals and water Phase two: Provision of food parcels, hygiene kits and shelter-improvement kits for eligible families affected by the explosion. title.narrative: DM and WASH support to communities in Yemen

description.narrative: This intervention builds on EnhancedÂ Vulnerability and Capacity Assessments (EVCA) conducted as part of the previous BRC-supported DM project in Yemen.Â Using theÂ recommendations from theÂ EVCAâ€™sÂ as a basis,Â theÂ project for 2020Â will focus onÂ buildingÂ disaster risk reduction throughÂ twoÂ approaches:Â 1)Â community-basedÂ preparednessÂ (including supporting the NS to efficiently and effectively deliver these services)Â 2)Â riskÂ mitigationÂ and DRRÂ measuresÂ particularly focused onÂ WASH support.Â These areas of focus aim to ensure the recommendationsÂ specifically identifiedÂ by the communitiesÂ are metÂ toÂ help reduce their vulnerabilityÂ and meet their immediate needs.Â The overall goal is toÂ Â reduceÂ theÂ vulnerability of communities in Yemen to the effects ofÂ the ongoing humanitarian crisis, exacerbated by recurrentÂ naturalÂ andÂ man-madeÂ hazards. As part of this project, contingency planning and EWS will be established, essential relief material prepositioned, DRR activities will be implemented and access to water ensured for 16 communities across 4 governorates (Shabwa, Al Mahra, Amran, Dhamar).Â Taking into consideration the current pandemic of COVID-19, the programme will also include risk communication and awareness sessions on hygiene promotion.

title.narrative: Myanmar Northern Rakhine project

description.narrative: The project will address the primary and secondary impact of Covid-19 in Maungdaw and Minbya township in Rakhine, supporting the implementation of preventative measures, increasing awareness and addressing basic needs of vulnerable communities in two townships in Rakhine. In addition, the project aims to enhance the capacity of MRCSâ€™ township branches and strengthen linkages between the branch and the network of community volunteers, which are critical to the success of the project. Â In the short term, 5 villages will be able to successfully form community volunteer groups which fosters sustained linkages with the Township branch. In the long term, it is expected that these linkages will be mobilised to support a community led resilience building, as discussed in the Lessons section above. This approach will be integrated into the Covid-19 recovery phase and addressing the secondary impacts of Covid-19. The project includes: 1) COVID awareness sessions, through the approach of RCCE, MRCS will conduct COVID-19 awareness sessio in the targeted communities. 2) Community level cloth mask making, community level volunteers will be organised and trained to undertake community level cloth mask making activities in selected villages. Community level tailors will be enaged in the process pf producing mask under tehcnial supervision and guidance of MRCS. 3) Community level hand soap making, the village colunteer groups thorugh active participation of community members will undertake hand wash soap making acvities and the liquid soap will be distributed among village schools and other common community meeting places, including monastaries and community quarantie facilities within villages. 4) Community quarantine facility management support will focus on supporting community quarantine facilities managed by village admistration and committees prioritizing required materials based on the needs identified such as water storage, batteries for electricity and other basic supplies. 5) Cssh for basic needs to the most vulnerable people undergoing community quarantine in targeted communities with one-time cash transfer of MMK 35,000 meeting basic needs of people 6) Training and buioding capacity of MRCS branch and red cross volunteers to support the COVID response Â Â Â Â Â

title.narrative: Integrating TB and malaria services into Maternal and Neonatal Child Health

description.narrative:
In Ethiopia, approximately 68% of the population is at risk of malaria with nearly a million people detected annually. The TB incidence in 2018 was 151 per 100,000, with yearly detection exceeding 110,000. More than three million women give birth annually in Ethiopia and are equally or more at risk of acquiring malaria or TB. The aforementioned complexities of these diseases in maternal and child health apply to all parts of Ethiopia. However, the four regions of Afar, Benishangul-Gumuz, Gambella, and Somali are more likely to be affected due to relatively weak health systems and poor health seeking behaviours. These regions have vulnerable communities due to their pastoralist and semi pastoralist lifestyles and are also affected by calamities such as droughts and disease outbreaks.
Amref operates in these areas to mainly implement Reproductive Maternal Neonatal and Child Health programs. Through an existing Amref-led Transform HDR project, Amref will contribute towards tackling these challenges. The existing project aims to increase health access and address vulnerable communities. The first intermediate result of Transform HDR focusses on access to healthcare, mainly maternal and child health (MCH) and malaria, in the developing regional states of Afar, Benishangul-Gumuz, Gambella and Somali.
Through this programme, Amref will continue to address the gaps in malaria and TB in mothers and children, in order to build upon current achievements and maximise impact. Additionally, to combat the detrimental effects of COVID-19, each activity will consider preventative measures such as physical distancing, hand hygiene and appropriate use of face masks.

The programme will train 320 health workers on malaria diagnosis/management, 375 health workers on TB diagnosis/management and 70 lab technicians on proper diagnosis and EQA mechanism. The project will also directly reach 72 health centres, 3 hospitals and 295 community health posts for EQAs/diagnosis quality assessments.

The programme’s overall objective is to improve prevention, detection, diagnosis and management of TB and malaria among mothers and children in developing regional states of Ethiopia. Specific objectives are: (1) Improve the capacity of frontline health workers for effective diagnosis, referrals and treatment of TB and malaria among women and children by integrating with MCH activities; (2) External Quality Assurance (EQA) on laboratory services for malaria, TB and lab services for ANC; (3) Knowledge management to improve integrated programming to strengthen PHC as a means to UHC. Project outcomes will be (1) 80% of targeted health workers can effectively diagnose and manage TB and malaria among ANC and under 5 clinic followers, (2) 95% EQA Concordance rate for malaria and TB diagnostics in over 80% of health facilities, and (3) 80% of data completeness from targeted health facilities

title.narrative: Stop the Spread COVID-19 in Amhara, Ethiopia

description.narrative: This project aims to train 8,000 health extension workers (HEWs) in the Amhara region through Amref's mobile digital training platform LEAP. The HEWs will be trained using a COVID-19 curriculum developed with the MoH focussing on key topics including community-based tracing, prevention and management of COVID-19, and measures to contain the spread.
This project is part of Amref's co-ordinated response to Stop the Spread and Flatten the Curve in 8 priority countries across Africa.
This project will be directly targeting 8,000 HEWs to gain knowledge that will indirectly benefit households in the Amhara region

title.narrative: Reproductive Health and Access to Water, Sanitation and Hygiene in Kajiado County, Kenya

description.narrative:
Kajiado County is a rural county in the south-east of Kenya, bordering Nairobi to the North, and Tanzania to the South. It is home to Maasai communities, including Nice Nailantei Leng’ete, Amref’s Global Ambassador to End Female Genital Mutilation or Cutting (FGM/C), who has been working for many years to reduce FGM/C across the region. Amref has been working in Kajiado County for 11 years. Over the last three years Amref, with funding from Stitching Ondersteuningsfonds Zorg Welzijn en Sport (ZWS), has been delivering the ARPWASH Model project in Kajiado. Through integrated Alternative Rites of Passage and WASH interventions, this project aimed to improve Sexual Reproductive Health Services and Rights (SRHR) among adolescent girls and women of reproductive age. The project will end in June 2020, having reached 27,691 people. As a result of the project 23 villages have been declared Open Defecation Free (ODF) communities and 2,725 adolescent girls were trained on SRHR, life skills, and hygiene, and graduated through Community-Led Alternative Rites of Passage (C-ARP) instead of going through FGM/C. A recent evaluation of Amref’s C-ARP programme in Kajiado County has shown that CL-ARP plays a decisive role in decreasing FGM/C, child, early and forced marriage. Since the programme started, FGM/C rates among girls in the region have declined by 24.2%, girls on average stayed in school for 2.5 years longer, and were more likely to delay marriage and childbirth, with teenage pregnancy declining by 6.3%. Women in Kajiado County bear the greatest burden when it comes to access to healthcare and water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH). Women are at risk of complications from pregnancy and childbirth, early marriages, unwanted pregnancy, and FGM/C. There is also increasing evidence that the reproductive health of women and girls is disproportionately affected by lack of access to WASH services, due to biological and cultural factors. Integrating WASH practices into health service delivery in health facilities and improving access to WASH within communities has been shown to decrease both morbidity and mortality of women and girls. WASH interventions are cost effective and help to improve gender equality and human rights by giving women and girls more social freedom and safety and removing inequitable work burdens. The COVID-19 pandemic, and resulting movement restrictions and school closures, has disrupted access to critical Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) services and hampered authorities’ ability to respond to Gender Based Violence (GBV) and harmful practices like FGM/C, child, early and forced marriages and teenage pregnancies. Reports of these have risen over recent months and reduced physical interaction between health workers and community members has hampered the ability to track and monitor girls at risk of FGM/C enrolled on Amref’s C-ARP programme.
Amref's second phase of the ARPWASH model project to improve the health and well-being of women of reproductive age in Kajiado by integrating SRHR, C-ARP and WASH interventions. The second phase will address gaps that have been identified during Phase One, many of which have been exacerbated by Covid-19: 1. Lack of online Tracking/Monitoring tool for 2,725 girls reached through the C-ARP 2. At least 1,500 girls still at risk of FGMC, early marriage and unintended pregnancy 3. At least 3,000 people still not reached with clean water sanitation and hygiene 4. Seven villages (1,750 people) still practicing open defecation still practicing open defecation 5. Limited public health infection, prevention and control measures With funding from the Rabelais Trust, we propose to fill these gaps by: 1. Training 90 Community Health Workers (CHWs) through our Leap digital platform on infection prevention at community and health facilities 2. Supporting 1,500 girls at risk of FGM/C in the 7 villages 3. Providing access to clean water for over 3,000 people in 7 villages. 4. Supporting 7 villages (Shompole, Kilonito, Maparasha, Meto, Kiloh, Olenarau and Olgulului) to become ODF and FGM/C free communities. 5. Attaching a trained CHW to each village to monitor and report all forms of violence against women and girls including FGM/C, domestic violence and Early Child and Forced Marriages (CEFM). By the end of the project we aim to meet the following objectives: 1. To improve infection prevention and control (IPC) among the target group(s). 2. To reduce cases of FGM/C, early marriage and teenage pregnancy among targeted communities 3. To increase acceptance and support for the C-ARP model by cultural and political leaders. 4. To generate evidence, share lessons learnt and best practices for ending FGM/C, early marriage and teenage pregnancy.

title.narrative: Stop the Spread COVID-19, Kenya

description.narrative: The project will train 2,000 HCPs and 4,500 CHWs

This project aims to train community health workers (CHWs) and healthcare professionals (HCPs) using Amref's mobile digital platforms (LEAP and JIBU) on a MoH approved curriculum for COVID-19. This covers key relevant topics such as home-based care and monitoring tools (for CHWs) and infection, prevention, control measures and rapid response for COVID-19 (for HCPs).
The project also aims to support mental health initiatives including a mental health training manual and key messages.
This project is part of Amref's co-ordinated response to Stop the Spread and Flatten the Curve in 8 priority countries across Africa.

title.narrative: Empowering communities to challenge FGM and prevent COVID-19 in Gabiley

description.narrative:
This project aims to replicate the successful approaches of FGM prevention projects previously supported by the Adelman Foundation, and combine COVID-19 prevention messaging to ensure the wide range of community representatives involved in challenging FGM are also able to share lifesaving information on COVID-19.
The COVID-19 prevention activities will reach 16,000 households, directly benefitting approximately 96,000 people. By supporting Somaliland’s efforts to reduce the spread and impact of COVID-19, we hope to strengthen our FGM programme. The FGM component of this project will directly benefit 1,208 people living in rural communities of Gabiley District, indirectly benefitting tens of thousands more through the sharing of information and influencing up to 20,000 people through media programmes.
